MUSICAL CLUB TO HOLD

LAST CONCERT BEFORE
EXAMINATIONS •

ANOTHER DANCE
TOMORROW NIGHT
Success
crowning
the
achievements of their latest
venture, the Cotillon Club will
hold another dance Saturday
night in the C. E. Hall, from
9 to 12 o'clock. Once more
the Blue Jay Orchestra will
furnish melodies to tickle the
toes of tired but intrepid undergraduates.
The cost of having one's
toes tickled will again be set
at one dollar a man, whether
accompanied by a bit of femininity or not. There will be
no dance next week because
of impending exams.

UTOPIAN COMPROMISE
The Student Council, it seems, has proposed a new plan for
freshmen regulations. This proposal is very ingenious. Lovers
of tradition are satisfied by the assurance that regulations will
go on as usual, while the disagreeable element of paddling is
eliminated. The plan has only one drawback; it won't work.
There is no doubt that the "moral suasion" which is substituted
for the strong arm methods of the past would not be just as effective. The difficulty lies in creating an attitude on the campus
that would exercise this "moral suasion." Such a state of mind
does not exist now; and it cannot be created by issuing an edict.
The proposed plan appears to be a compromise between the
ideas that paddling is bad and that regulations are good. Nothing
could be worse for the campus morale than the laying down of
rules which would not be followed. What is needed is not a compromise, but a definite choice. Either strict enforcement of regulations should be provided for, or they should be abolished. Separate provisions, however, might be made for the rules calling
for attendance at games, and participation in activities. With this
exception, there is no practical middle course.

BY WAY OF APPRECIATION
Dear Toots,
Do you know, Toots, that right few girls, particularly ones

I have truly felt the spirit behind the gift of that beautifully
chosen and excellently colored scarf.
John Blott dropped in this afternoon to make a very delightful visit. He left me, with due greetings, in possession of a bottle
of Henessy's Three Star Cognac that he remembered he got in
France and packed away in careful moment. He's been gone
about an hour now and I have packed some of it in careless

to live in? Can't you just picture the celebration of Noel, and

get fortified with some Three Star. . .

ACTORS ENTERTAINED

COPEAU VISITS

BIRDS OF PAY
A local moving picture theatre is advertising the advent of
"Enoch Light and his famous 'Blue jays,' who have been making vaudeville history in their flight about the country." They are
to be seen in Baltimore next week. The advertisement goes on to
say that "The 'Blue Jays' are graduates of J. H. U., Class of '26."
It is our opinion that this is advertising under false pretenses. The Blue Jay Orchestra started out last summer on a
vaudeville circuit with about half its members Hopkins men.
Gradually the orchestra came to be an organization made up
of men who had never gone to Hopkins. Finally, only Light and
one other FIopkins man remained.
That is the organization which will appear in Baltimore next
week, and it cannot be truthfully said to consist of "graduates
of J. H. U., Class of '26," and should certainly not be advertised in connection with Johns Hopkins.
The orchestra itself said when they first embarked that they
would not use Hopkins' name in connection with their act. They
have not abided by their promise and do not seem to us to be
fit to receive the support of the student body.

In Paris in 1913 M. Copeau organized the Vieux Colombier Theatre and was quite successful in
this project, but due to ill health
and the war was forced to withdraw.
In 1917 he was sent to America
by the French government for two
years. On his return to France he
purchased a home in Burgundy,
where he .now has a troupe of
young actors and actresses, furnishing them with food and lodging.
During three months of each year
this group tours a few of the European countries, playing in the larger cities on the Continent, the last
tour being made through Sweden

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 14, 1927

Y. M. C. A. Conference's
Attitude Defended
By Local President
By ROBERT L. BULL
Much has been reported in criticism of the Milwaukee Conference
and yet there are several things of
a positive and constructive nature
to be said about it.
1. The attitude of the conterence was distinctly unfavorable to
the nationalistic policies of our government, and, especially unfavorable
with regard to the militaristic program employed in carrying out this
policy. A great number of foreign
students were present, representatives of every nation in the world
of any size. The endorsement of
the views of the conference by three
thousand American youths will certainly tend to produce an attitude of
good-will towards our country on
the part of these foreign students.

JAY TO BE INNOVATION

to be found in the world today. The
medieval, "Santa Claus" conception
of God, was attributed to the conference only by the "Menckenites"
present. Suffice it to say, they had
nothing better to offer. Substantially, the view adhered to by the
delegates was that God is a loving
Personality at work in an orderly
Universe and, that men could be coworkers with Him or sharers in the
great process of creation.
In our attempt to understand this
process it was held that there was
no conflict between science. and religion. One supplements the other;
hut, one used without the other is
necessarily limiting our capacities
and opportunities to bring about a
new social order.
5. It is safe to say that the benefits of the conference will be widely felt and shared. "There are none
So blind as those who will not see."
The conference had nothing to offer to that type of student. Its program was an honest attempt to meet
certain needs of the youth in America and its success will be most
largely measured by its influence on
the lives it touched.

2. The difficult problem of racial relationships, was undertaken
in a spirit of sympathy with an earnest desire to change prevailing attitudes of prejudice and discrimination. It was pointed out that we
must remove the stigma of inferiority, which we have -assumed towards other races, in order to cooperate with them effectively in promoting a desirable program of social reform.
3. The conference accomplished
the hitherto unattainable, namely,
the articulation of widespread student opinion on the major issues of
both student and national life.
Moreover, the smug complacency
and narrow provincialism of isolated student bodies disappeared in
the presence of such a representative student gathering. One was
forced to revise many opinions
about student life in the light of
discussion between men from widely scattered universities.
4. In the opinion of the majority, the conference voiced the most
promising and intelligent.view; concerning religion and science that are

Transportation Division, of the
Westinghouse Sales Department,located at New York.

large organization?" That
is what college men want to know,
first of all. The question is best
answered by the accomplishments
of others with similar training
and like opportunities. This is
one of a series of advertisements
portraying Me progress at Westinghouse of college graduates,
of the campus some five—eight
—ten years.

LAWRENCE DAY
HOWELL

When Howell came from college to the Westinghouse Graduate Students' Course, he had
twelve months of thoroughgoing work in the shops at East
Pittsburgh. Then he decided
he wanted to enter the field
which seemed most undeveloped

and perhaps most promising
of broad expansion. This was
marine engineering.
Not five per cent of the present opportunities on the water
have been opened for electrification. Yet there is more horsepower, in prime movers, on the
ocean than there is on the land.
In Howell's undergraduate

days, this field was scarcely
scratched—just as radio was not
known to many young engineers
when they were in college. A
college man's opportunities are
not limited to the electrical developments now in existence.
In marine applications an order may assume large proportions. A single installation,
negotiated by Howell recently,
of the newly-developed Dieselelectric drive for a yacht, totaled
$175,000. Such sales are not
made overnight. They result
from understanding fully a customer's needs.
To men with the knack of
taking the other fellow's point
of view, a career as Sales Engineer at Westinghouse brings returns in personal satisfaction as
well as in worldly reward.

Westinghouse

DORM DOINGS

EDDIE HILL'S SECOND ARTICLE

A group of the entry "B" boys
ably directed by one graduate student of history are reported to have
caused some disorder in the belongings and furniture of an assistant
business manager of the NEWS-LETTER, Irving Hoffman, '28. The results seemed to have been particularly disastrous in their effect upon the gentleman's bed.

Insurance
Sergeant Frank Has
Picture Snapped
Seated on the edge of the wellknown fountain which sprays its
limpid waters in front of the Barn,
Sergeant Frank had his picture
taken last week in a very novel setting. On either side of Frank in
extremely fetching poses sat. two of
Hopkins' fair coeds. Both are well
known to campus Romeos and the
incident furnished a very welcome
diversion since it occurred just at
lunch time. The picture was taken
by Vernon Scheidt, Hullabaloo photographer, at the instigation of
"Doc" Adams, university food dispenser.

MUSICAL CLUB TO HOLD

LAST CONCERT BEFORE
EXAMINATIONS •

ANOTHER DANCE
TOMORROW NIGHT
Success
crowning
the
achievements of their latest
venture, the Cotillon Club will
hold another dance Saturday
night in the C. E. Hall, from
9 to 12 o'clock. Once more
the Blue Jay Orchestra will
furnish melodies to tickle the
toes of tired but intrepid undergraduates.
The cost of having one's
toes tickled will again be set
at one dollar a man, whether
accompanied by a bit of femininity or not. There will be
no dance next week because
of impending exams.

UTOPIAN COMPROMISE
The Student Council, it seems, has proposed a new plan for
freshmen regulations. This proposal is very ingenious. Lovers
of tradition are satisfied by the assurance that regulations will
go on as usual, while the disagreeable element of paddling is
eliminated. The plan has only one drawback; it won't work.
There is no doubt that the "moral suasion" which is substituted
for the strong arm methods of the past would not be just as effective. The difficulty lies in creating an attitude on the campus
that would exercise this "moral suasion." Such a state of mind
does not exist now; and it cannot be created by issuing an edict.
The proposed plan appears to be a compromise between the
ideas that paddling is bad and that regulations are good. Nothing
could be worse for the campus morale than the laying down of
rules which would not be followed. What is needed is not a compromise, but a definite choice. Either strict enforcement of regulations should be provided for, or they should be abolished. Separate provisions, however, might be made for the rules calling
for attendance at games, and participation in activities. With this
exception, there is no practical middle course.

ACTORS ENTERTAINED

COPEAU VISITS
Continued from Page 1, Col.

BIRDS OF PAY
A local moving picture theatre is advertising the advent of
"Enoch Light and his famous 'Blue jays,' who have been making vaudeville history in their flight about the country." They are
to be seen in Baltimore next week. The advertisement goes on to
say that "The 'Blue Jays' are graduates of J. H. U., Class of '26."
It is our opinion that this is advertising under false pretenses. The Blue Jay Orchestra started out last summer on a
vaudeville circuit with about half its members Hopkins men.
Gradually the orchestra came to be an organization made up
of men who had never gone to Hopkins. Finally, only Light and
one other FIopkins man remained.
That is the organization which will appear in Baltimore next
week, and it cannot be truthfully said to consist of "graduates
of J. H. U., Class of '26," and should certainly not be advertised in connection with Johns Hopkins.
The orchestra itself said when they first embarked that they
would not use Hopkins' name in connection with their act. They
have not abided by their promise and do not seem to us to be
fit to receive the support of the student body.

In Paris in 1913 M. Copeau organized the Vieux Colombier Theatre and was quite successful in
this project, but due to ill health
and the war was forced to withdraw.
In 1917 he was sent to America
by the French government for two
years. On his return to France he
purchased a home in Burgundy,
where he .now has a troupe of
young actors and actresses, furnishing them with food and lodging.
During three months of each year
this group tours a few of the European countries, playing in the larger cities on the Continent, the last
tour being made through Sweden

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 14, 1927

Y. M. C. A. Conference's
Attitude Defended
By Local President
By ROBERT L. BULL
Much has been reported in criticism of the Milwaukee Conference
and yet there are several things of
a positive and constructive nature
to be said about it.
1. The attitude of the conterence was distinctly unfavorable to
the nationalistic policies of our government, and, especially unfavorable
with regard to the militaristic program employed in carrying out this
policy. A great number of foreign
students were present, representatives of every nation in the world
of any size. The endorsement of
the views of the conference by three
thousand American youths will certainly tend to produce an attitude of
good-will towards our country on
the part of these foreign students.

JAY TO BE INNOVATION

to be found in the world today. The
medieval, "Santa Claus" conception
of God, was attributed to the conference only by the "Menckenites"
present. Suffice it to say, they had
nothing better to offer. Substantially, the view adhered to by the
delegates was that God is a loving
Personality at work in an orderly
Universe and, that men could be coworkers with Him or sharers in the
great process of creation.
In our attempt to understand this
process it was held that there was
no conflict between science. and religion. One supplements the other;
hut, one used without the other is
necessarily limiting our capacities
and opportunities to bring about a
new social order.
5. It is safe to say that the benefits of the conference will be widely felt and shared. "There are none
So blind as those who will not see."
The conference had nothing to offer to that type of student. Its program was an honest attempt to meet
certain needs of the youth in America and its success will be most
largely measured by its influence on
the lives it touched.

2. The difficult problem of racial relationships, was undertaken
in a spirit of sympathy with an earnest desire to change prevailing attitudes of prejudice and discrimination. It was pointed out that we
must remove the stigma of inferiority, which we have -assumed towards other races, in order to cooperate with them effectively in promoting a desirable program of social reform.
3. The conference accomplished
the hitherto unattainable, namely,
the articulation of widespread student opinion on the major issues of
both student and national life.
Moreover, the smug complacency
and narrow provincialism of isolated student bodies disappeared in
the presence of such a representative student gathering. One was
forced to revise many opinions
about student life in the light of
discussion between men from widely scattered universities.
4. In the opinion of the majority, the conference voiced the most
promising and intelligent.view; concerning religion and science that are

What he didn't learn
at college

In his class work,

"What's thefuture with a

Lawrence Day
Howell, Princeton, Litt. B. '13,
E. E. '19, never
heard of marine
applications for
electrical equipment. In fact, they were practically unknown. Yet he now is
in charge of the Marine Section,
Transportation Division, of the
Westinghouse Sales Department,located at New York.

large organization?" That
is what college men want to know,
first of all. The question is best
answered by the accomplishments
of others with similar training
and like opportunities. This is
one of a series of advertisements
portraying Me progress at Westinghouse of college graduates,
of the campus some five—eight
—ten years.

LAWRENCE DAY
HOWELL

When Howell came from college to the Westinghouse Graduate Students' Course, he had
twelve months of thoroughgoing work in the shops at East
Pittsburgh. Then he decided
he wanted to enter the field
which seemed most undeveloped

and perhaps most promising
of broad expansion. This was
marine engineering.
Not five per cent of the present opportunities on the water
have been opened for electrification. Yet there is more horsepower, in prime movers, on the
ocean than there is on the land.
In Howell's undergraduate

days, this field was scarcely
scratched—just as radio was not
known to many young engineers
when they were in college. A
college man's opportunities are
not limited to the electrical developments now in existence.
In marine applications an order may assume large proportions. A single installation,
negotiated by Howell recently,
of the newly-developed Dieselelectric drive for a yacht, totaled
$175,000. Such sales are not
made overnight. They result
from understanding fully a customer's needs.
To men with the knack of
taking the other fellow's point
of view, a career as Sales Engineer at Westinghouse brings returns in personal satisfaction as
well as in worldly reward.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 14, 1927

4

DORM DOINGS

EDDIE HILL'S SECOND ARTICLE
ON ART OF SWIMMING CRAWL

A group of the entry "B" boys
ably directed by one graduate student of history are reported to have
caused some disorder in the belongings and furniture of an assistant
business manager of the NEWS-LETTER, Irving Hoffman, '28. The results seemed to have been particularly disastrous in their effect upon the gentleman's bed.

EDITOR'S NOTE: This is the second of Coach Hill's "Lessons
in the Crawl Stroke." The NEWS-LETTER recommends saving
the entire series for summer practice.

The practice of singing merry
songs on Sunday evenings has apparently been discontinued, perhaps
due to the objections made by the
residents of the Greenway apPrtment. Much credit is deserved by
the good people of the Greenway
for eliminating the danger of increasipg the jolly good fellowship
among the dormitory boys.

Insurance
Sergeant Frank Has
Picture Snapped
Seated on the edge of the wellknown fountain which sprays its
limpid waters in front of the Barn,
Sergeant Frank had his picture
taken last week in a very novel setting. On either side of Frank in
extremely fetching poses sat. two of
Hopkins' fair coeds. Both are well
known to campus Romeos and the
incident furnished a very welcome
diversion since it occurred just at
lunch time. The picture was taken
by Vernon Scheidt, Hullabaloo photographer, at the instigation of
"Doc" Adams, university food dispenser.
